speaker: FLAVIUS
text: Hence! Home, you idle creatures, get you home! Is this a holiday? What, know you not, Being mechanical, you ought not walk Upon a laboring day without the sign Of your profession?—Speak, what trade art thou?

speaker: CARPENTER
text: Why, sir, a carpenter.

speaker: MARULLUS
text: Where is thy leather apron and thy rule? What dost thou with thy best apparel on?— You, sir, what trade are you?

speaker: COBBLER
text: Truly, sir, in respect of a fine workman, I am but, as you would say, a cobbler.

speaker: MARULLUS
text: But what trade art thou? Answer me directly.

speaker: COBBLER
text: A trade, sir, that I hope I may use with a safe conscience, which is indeed, sir, a mender of bad soles.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text: What trade, thou knave? Thou naughty knave, what trade?

speaker: COBBLER
text: Nay, I beseech you, sir, be not out with me. Yet if you be out, sir, I can mend you.

speaker: MARULLUS
text: What mean’st thou by that? Mend me, thou saucy fellow?

speaker: COBBLER
text: Why, sir, cobble you.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text: Thou art a cobbler, art thou?

speaker: COBBLER
text: Truly, sir, all that I live by is with the awl. I meddle with no tradesman’s matters nor women’s matters, but withal I am indeed, sir, a surgeon to old shoes: when they are in great danger, I recover them. As proper men as ever trod upon neat’s leather have gone upon my handiwork.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text: But wherefore art not in thy shop today? Why dost thou lead these men about the streets?

speaker: COBBLER
text: Truly, sir, to wear out their shoes, to get myself into more work. But indeed, sir, we make holiday to see Caesar and to rejoice in his triumph.

speaker: MARULLUS
text: Wherefore rejoice? What conquest brings he home? What tributaries follow him to Rome To grace in captive bonds his chariot wheels? You blocks, you stones, you worse than senseless things! O you hard hearts, you cruel men of Rome, Knew you not Pompey? Many a time and oft Have you climbed up to walls and battlements, To towers and windows, yea, to chimney tops, Your infants in your arms, and there have sat The livelong day, with patient expectation, To see great Pompey pass the streets of Rome. And when you saw his chariot but appear, Have you not made an universal shout, That Tiber trembled underneath her banks

speaker: FLAVIUS
text: Go, go, good countrymen, and for this fault Assemble all the poor men of your sort, Draw them to Tiber banks, and weep your tears Into the channel, till the lowest stream Do kiss the most exalted shores of all. All the Commoners exit. See whe’er their basest mettle be not moved. They vanish tongue-tied in their guiltiness. Go you down that way towards the Capitol. This way will I. Disrobe the images If you do find them decked with ceremonies.

speaker: MARULLUS
text: May we do so? You know it is the feast of Lupercal.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text: It is no matter. Let no images Be hung with Caesar’s trophies. I’ll about And drive away the vulgar from the streets; So do you too, where you perceive them thick. These growing feathers plucked from Caesar’s wing Will make him fly an ordinary pitch, Who else would soar above the view of men And keep us all in servile fearfulness. They exit in different directions.

speaker: CAESAR
text: Calphurnia.

speaker: CASCA
text: Peace, ho! Caesar speaks.

speaker: CAESAR
text: Calphurnia.

speaker: CALPHURNIA
text: Here, my lord.

speaker: CAESAR
text: Stand you directly in Antonius’ way When he doth run his course.—Antonius.

speaker: ANTONY
text: Caesar, my lord.

speaker: CAESAR
text: Forget not in your speed, Antonius, To touch Calphurnia, for our elders say The barren, touchèd in this holy chase, Shake off their sterile curse.

speaker: ANTONY
text: I shall remember. When Caesar says “Do this,” it is performed.

speaker: CAESAR
text: Set on and leave no ceremony out. Sennet.

speaker: SOOTHSAYER
text: Caesar.

speaker: CAESAR
text: Ha! Who calls?

speaker: CASCA
text: Bid every noise be still. Peace, yet again!

speaker: CAESAR
text: Who is it in the press that calls on me? I hear a tongue shriller than all the music Cry “Caesar.” Speak. Caesar is turned to hear.

speaker: SOOTHSAYER
text: Beware the ides of March.

speaker: CAESAR
text: What man is that?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: A soothsayer bids you beware the ides of March.

speaker: CAESAR
text: Set him before me. Let me see his face.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Fellow, come from the throng. The Soothsayer comes forward. Look upon Caesar.

speaker: CAESAR
text: What sayst thou to me now? Speak once again.

speaker: SOOTHSAYER
text: Beware the ides of March.

speaker: CAESAR
text: He is a dreamer. Let us leave him. Pass. Sennet. All but Brutus and Cassius exit.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Will you go see the order of the course?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Not I.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: I pray you, do.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: I am not gamesome. I do lack some part Of that quick spirit that is in Antony. Let me not hinder, Cassius, your desires. I’ll leave you.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Brutus, I do observe you now of late. I have not from your eyes that gentleness And show of love as I was wont to have. You bear too stubborn and too strange a hand Over your friend that loves you.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Cassius, Be not deceived. If I have veiled my look, I turn the trouble of my countenance Merely upon myself. Vexèd I am Of late with passions of some difference, Conceptions only proper to myself, Which give some soil, perhaps, to my behaviors. But let not therefore my good friends be grieved (Among which number, Cassius, be you one)

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Then, Brutus, I have much mistook your passion, By means whereof this breast of mine hath buried Thoughts of great value, worthy cogitations. Tell me, good Brutus, can you see your face?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: No, Cassius, for the eye sees not itself But by reflection, by some other things.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: ’Tis just. And it is very much lamented, Brutus, That you have no such mirrors as will turn Your hidden worthiness into your eye, That you might see your shadow. I have heard Where many of the best respect in Rome, Except immortal Caesar, speaking of Brutus And groaning underneath this age’s yoke, Have wished that noble Brutus had his eyes.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Into what dangers would you lead me, Cassius, That you would have me seek into myself For that which is not in me?

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Therefore, good Brutus, be prepared to hear. And since you know you cannot see yourself So well as by reflection, I, your glass, Will modestly discover to yourself That of yourself which you yet know not of. And be not jealous on me, gentle Brutus. Were I a common laughter, or did use To stale with ordinary oaths my love To every new protester; if you know That I do fawn on men and hug them hard And after scandal them, or if you know

speaker: BRUTUS
text: What means this shouting? I do fear the people Choose Caesar for their king.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Ay, do you fear it? Then must I think you would not have it so.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: I would not, Cassius, yet I love him well. But wherefore do you hold me here so long? What is it that you would impart to me? If it be aught toward the general good, Set honor in one eye and death i’ th’ other And I will look on both indifferently; For let the gods so speed me as I love The name of honor more than I fear death.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: I know that virtue to be in you, Brutus, As well as I do know your outward favor. Well, honor is the subject of my story. I cannot tell what you and other men Think of this life; but, for my single self, I had as lief not be as live to be In awe of such a thing as I myself. I was born free as Caesar; so were you; We both have fed as well, and we can both Endure the winter’s cold as well as he. For once, upon a raw and gusty day, The troubled Tiber chafing with her shores, Caesar said to me “Dar’st thou, Cassius, now Leap in with me into this angry flood And swim to yonder point?” Upon the word, Accoutered as I was, I plungèd in And bade him follow; so indeed he did. The torrent roared, and we did buffet it

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Another general shout! I do believe that these applauses are For some new honors that are heaped on Caesar.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Why, man, he doth bestride the narrow world Like a Colossus, and we petty men Walk under his huge legs and peep about To find ourselves dishonorable graves. Men at some time are masters of their fates. The fault, dear Brutus, is not in our stars, But in ourselves, that we are underlings.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: That you do love me, I am nothing jealous. What you would work me to, I have some aim. How I have thought of this, and of these times, I shall recount hereafter. For this present, I would not, so with love I might entreat you, Be any further moved. What you have said I will consider; what you have to say I will with patience hear, and find a time Both meet to hear and answer such high things. Till then, my noble friend, chew upon this: Brutus had rather be a villager Than to repute himself a son of Rome

speaker: CASSIUS
text: I am glad that my weak words Have struck but thus much show of fire from Brutus. Enter Caesar and his train.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: The games are done, and Caesar is returning.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: As they pass by, pluck Casca by the sleeve, And he will, after his sour fashion, tell you What hath proceeded worthy note today.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: I will do so. But look you, Cassius, The angry spot doth glow on Caesar’s brow, And all the rest look like a chidden train. Calphurnia’s cheek is pale, and Cicero Looks with such ferret and such fiery eyes As we have seen him in the Capitol, Being crossed in conference by some senators.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Casca will tell us what the matter is.

speaker: CAESAR
text: Antonius.

speaker: ANTONY
text: Caesar.

speaker: CAESAR
text: Let me have men about me that are fat, Sleek-headed men, and such as sleep a-nights. Yond Cassius has a lean and hungry look. He thinks too much. Such men are dangerous.

speaker: ANTONY
text: Fear him not, Caesar; he’s not dangerous. He is a noble Roman, and well given.

speaker: CAESAR
text: Would he were fatter! But I fear him not. Yet if my name were liable to fear,

speaker: CASCA
text: You pulled me by the cloak. Would you speak with me?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Ay, Casca. Tell us what hath chanced today That Caesar looks so sad.

speaker: CASCA
text: Why, you were with him, were you not?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: I should not then ask Casca what had chanced.

speaker: CASCA
text: Why, there was a crown offered him; and, being offered him, he put it by with the back of his hand, thus, and then the people fell a-shouting.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: What was the second noise for?

speaker: CASCA
text: Why, for that too.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: They shouted thrice. What was the last cry for?

speaker: CASCA
text: Why, for that too.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Was the crown offered him thrice?

speaker: CASCA
text: Ay, marry, was ’t, and he put it by thrice, every time gentler than other; and at every putting-by, mine honest neighbors shouted.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Who offered him the crown?

speaker: CASCA
text: Why, Antony.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Tell us the manner of it, gentle Casca.

speaker: CASCA
text: I can as well be hanged as tell the manner of it. It was mere foolery; I did not mark it. I saw Mark Antony offer him a crown (yet ’twas not a crown neither; ’twas one of these coronets), and, as I told you, he put it by once; but for all that, to my thinking, he would fain have had it. Then he offered it to him again; then he put it by again; but to my thinking, he was very loath to lay his fingers off it. And then he offered it the third time. He put it the third time by, and still as he refused it the rabblement hooted and clapped their chopped hands and threw up their sweaty nightcaps and uttered such a deal of stinking breath because Caesar refused the crown that it had almost choked Caesar, for he swooned and fell down at it. And for mine own part, I durst not laugh for fear of opening my lips and receiving the bad air.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: But soft, I pray you. What, did Caesar swoon?

speaker: CASCA
text: He fell down in the marketplace and foamed at mouth and was speechless.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: ’Tis very like; he hath the falling sickness.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: No, Caesar hath it not; but you and I And honest Casca, we have the falling sickness.

speaker: CASCA
text: I know not what you mean by that, but I am sure Caesar fell down. If the tag-rag people did not clap him and hiss him, according as he pleased and displeased them, as they use to do the players in the theater, I am no true man.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: What said he when he came unto himself?

speaker: CASCA
text: Marry, before he fell down, when he perceived the common herd was glad he refused the crown, he plucked me ope his doublet and offered them his throat to cut. An I had been a man of any occupation, if I would not have taken him at a word, I would I might go to hell among the rogues. And so he fell. When he came to himself again, he said if he had done or said anything amiss, he desired their Worships to think it was his infirmity. Three or four wenches where I stood cried “Alas, good soul!” and forgave him with all their hearts. But there’s no heed to be taken of them; if Caesar had stabbed their mothers, they would have done no less.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: And, after that, he came thus sad away?

speaker: CASCA
text: Ay.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Did Cicero say anything?

speaker: CASCA
text: Ay, he spoke Greek.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: To what effect?

speaker: CASCA
text: Nay, an I tell you that, I’ll ne’er look you i’ th’ face again. But those that understood him smiled at one another and shook their heads. But for mine own part, it was Greek to me. I could tell you more news too: Marullus and Flavius, for pulling scarves off Caesar’s images, are put to silence. Fare you well. There was more foolery yet, if I could remember it.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Will you sup with me tonight, Casca?

speaker: CASCA
text: No, I am promised forth.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Will you dine with me tomorrow?

speaker: CASCA
text: Ay, if I be alive, and your mind hold, and your dinner worth the eating.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Good. I will expect you.

speaker: CASCA
text: Do so. Farewell both. He exits.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: What a blunt fellow is this grown to be! He was quick mettle when he went to school.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: So is he now in execution Of any bold or noble enterprise, However he puts on this tardy form. This rudeness is a sauce to his good wit, Which gives men stomach to digest his words With better appetite.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: And so it is. For this time I will leave you. Tomorrow, if you please to speak with me, I will come home to you; or, if you will, Come home to me, and I will wait for you.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: I will do so. Till then, think of the world. Brutus exits. Well, Brutus, thou art noble. Yet I see Thy honorable mettle may be wrought From that it is disposed. Therefore it is meet That noble minds keep ever with their likes; For who so firm that cannot be seduced? Caesar doth bear me hard, but he loves Brutus. If I were Brutus now, and he were Cassius, He should not humor me. I will this night In several hands in at his windows throw, As if they came from several citizens, Writings, all tending to the great opinion That Rome holds of his name, wherein obscurely Caesar’s ambition shall be glancèd at And after this, let Caesar seat him sure, For we will shake him, or worse days endure. He exits.

speaker: CICERO
text: Good even, Casca. Brought you Caesar home? Why are you breathless? And why stare you so?

speaker: CASCA
text: Are not you moved, when all the sway of earth Shakes like a thing unfirm? O Cicero, I have seen tempests when the scolding winds Have rived the knotty oaks, and I have seen Th’ ambitious ocean swell and rage and foam To be exalted with the threat’ning clouds; But never till tonight, never till now, Did I go through a tempest dropping fire. Either there is a civil strife in heaven, Or else the world, too saucy with the gods, Incenses them to send destruction.

speaker: CICERO
text: Why, saw you anything more wonderful?

speaker: CASCA
text: A common slave (you know him well by sight) Held up his left hand, which did flame and burn Like twenty torches joined; and yet his hand, Not sensible of fire, remained unscorched. Besides (I ha’ not since put up my sword), Against the Capitol I met a lion, Who glazed upon me and went surly by Without annoying me. And there were drawn Upon a heap a hundred ghastly women, Transformèd with their fear, who swore they saw Men all in fire walk up and down the streets. And yesterday the bird of night did sit Even at noonday upon the marketplace, Hooting and shrieking. When these prodigies Do so conjointly meet, let not men say

speaker: CICERO
text: Indeed, it is a strange-disposèd time. But men may construe things after their fashion, Clean from the purpose of the things themselves. Comes Caesar to the Capitol tomorrow?

speaker: CASCA
text: He doth, for he did bid Antonius Send word to you he would be there tomorrow.

speaker: CICERO
text: Good night then, Casca. This disturbèd sky Is not to walk in.

speaker: CASCA
text: Farewell, Cicero Cicero exits. Enter Cassius.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Who’s there?

speaker: CASCA
text: A Roman.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Casca, by your voice.

speaker: CASCA
text: Your ear is good. Cassius, what night is this!

speaker: CASSIUS
text: A very pleasing night to honest men.

speaker: CASCA
text: Who ever knew the heavens menace so?

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Those that have known the Earth so full of faults. For my part, I have walked about the streets, Submitting me unto the perilous night, And thus unbracèd, Casca, as you see, Have bared my bosom to the thunder-stone; And when the cross blue lightning seemed to open The breast of heaven, I did present myself Even in the aim and very flash of it.

speaker: CASCA
text: But wherefore did you so much tempt the heavens? It is the part of men to fear and tremble When the most mighty gods by tokens send Such dreadful heralds to astonish us.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: You are dull, Casca, and those sparks of life That should be in a Roman you do want, Or else you use not. You look pale, and gaze, And put on fear, and cast yourself in wonder, To see the strange impatience of the heavens. But if you would consider the true cause Why all these fires, why all these gliding ghosts, Why birds and beasts from quality and kind, Why old men, fools, and children calculate, Why all these things change from their ordinance, Their natures, and preformèd faculties, To monstrous quality—why, you shall find That heaven hath infused them with these spirits To make them instruments of fear and warning Unto some monstrous state. Now could I, Casca, name to thee a man Most like this dreadful night, That thunders, lightens, opens graves, and roars As doth the lion in the Capitol; A man no mightier than thyself or me In personal action, yet prodigious grown, And fearful, as these strange eruptions are.

speaker: CASCA
text: ’Tis Caesar that you mean, is it not, Cassius?

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Let it be who it is. For Romans now Have thews and limbs like to their ancestors. But, woe the while, our fathers’ minds are dead, And we are governed with our mothers’ spirits. Our yoke and sufferance show us womanish.

speaker: CASCA
text: Indeed, they say the Senators tomorrow Mean to establish Caesar as a king, And he shall wear his crown by sea and land In every place save here in Italy.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: I know where I will wear this dagger then; Cassius from bondage will deliver Cassius. Therein, you gods, you make the weak most strong; Therein, you gods, you tyrants do defeat. Nor stony tower, nor walls of beaten brass, Nor airless dungeon, nor strong links of iron, Can be retentive to the strength of spirit; But life, being weary of these worldly bars, Never lacks power to dismiss itself. If I know this, know all the world besides, That part of tyranny that I do bear I can shake off at pleasure. Thunder still.

speaker: CASCA
text: So can I. So every bondman in his own hand bears The power to cancel his captivity.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: And why should Caesar be a tyrant, then? Poor man, I know he would not be a wolf But that he sees the Romans are but sheep; He were no lion, were not Romans hinds. Those that with haste will make a mighty fire Begin it with weak straws. What trash is Rome, What rubbish, and what offal when it serves For the base matter to illuminate So vile a thing as Caesar! But, O grief, Where hast thou led me? I perhaps speak this Before a willing bondman; then, I know My answer must be made. But I am armed, And dangers are to me indifferent.

speaker: CASCA
text: You speak to Casca, and to such a man That is no fleering telltale. Hold. My hand. They shake hands. Be factious for redress of all these griefs, And I will set this foot of mine as far As who goes farthest.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: There’s a bargain made. Now know you, Casca, I have moved already Some certain of the noblest-minded Romans To undergo with me an enterprise Of honorable-dangerous consequence. And I do know by this they stay for me In Pompey’s Porch. For now, this fearful night, There is no stir or walking in the streets; And the complexion of the element In favor ’s like the work we have in hand, Most bloody, fiery, and most terrible. Enter Cinna.

speaker: CASCA
text: Stand close awhile, for here comes one in haste.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: ’Tis Cinna; I do know him by his gait. He is a friend.—Cinna, where haste you so?

speaker: CINNA
text: To find out you. Who’s that? Metellus Cimber?

speaker: CASSIUS
text: No, it is Casca, one incorporate To our attempts. Am I not stayed for, Cinna?

speaker: CINNA
text: I am glad on ’t. What a fearful night is this! There’s two or three of us have seen strange sights.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Am I not stayed for? Tell me.

speaker: CINNA
text: Yes, you are. O Cassius, if you could But win the noble Brutus to our party—

speaker: CINNA
text: All but Metellus Cimber, and he’s gone To seek you at your house. Well, I will hie And so bestow these papers as you bade me.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: That done, repair to Pompey’s Theater. Cinna exits. Come, Casca, you and I will yet ere day See Brutus at his house. Three parts of him Is ours already, and the man entire Upon the next encounter yields him ours.

speaker: CASCA
text: O, he sits high in all the people’s hearts, And that which would appear offense in us His countenance, like richest alchemy, Will change to virtue and to worthiness.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Him and his worth and our great need of him You have right well conceited. Let us go, For it is after midnight, and ere day We will awake him and be sure of him. They exit.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: What, Lucius, ho!— I cannot by the progress of the stars Give guess how near to day.—Lucius, I say!— I would it were my fault to sleep so soundly.— When, Lucius, when? Awake, I say! What, Lucius! Enter Lucius.

speaker: LUCIUS
text: Called you, my lord?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Get me a taper in my study, Lucius. When it is lighted, come and call me here.

speaker: LUCIUS
text: I will, my lord. He exits.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: It must be by his death. And for my part I know no personal cause to spurn at him, But for the general. He would be crowned: How that might change his nature, there’s the question. It is the bright day that brings forth the adder, And that craves wary walking. Crown him that, And then I grant we put a sting in him That at his will he may do danger with. Th’ abuse of greatness is when it disjoins

speaker: LUCIUS
text: The taper burneth in your closet, sir. Searching the window for a flint, I found This paper, thus sealed up, and I am sure It did not lie there when I went to bed. Gives him the letter.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Get you to bed again. It is not day. Is not tomorrow, boy, the ides of March?

speaker: LUCIUS
text: I know not, sir.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Look in the calendar, and bring me word.

speaker: LUCIUS
text: I will, sir. He exits.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: The exhalations, whizzing in the air, Give so much light that I may read by them. Opens the letter and reads.

speaker: LUCIUS
text: Sir, March is wasted fifteen days. Knock within.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: ’Tis good. Go to the gate; somebody knocks. Lucius exits. Since Cassius first did whet me against Caesar, I have not slept. Between the acting of a dreadful thing And the first motion, all the interim is Like a phantasma or a hideous dream. The genius and the mortal instruments Are then in council, and the state of man, Like to a little kingdom, suffers then The nature of an insurrection. Enter Lucius.

speaker: LUCIUS
text: Sir, ’tis your brother Cassius at the door, Who doth desire to see you.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Is he alone?

speaker: LUCIUS
text: No, sir. There are more with him.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Do you know them?

speaker: LUCIUS
text: No, sir. Their hats are plucked about their ears, And half their faces buried in their cloaks, That by no means I may discover them By any mark of favor.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Let ’em enter. Lucius exits. They are the faction. O conspiracy, Sham’st thou to show thy dang’rous brow by night, When evils are most free? O, then, by day Where wilt thou find a cavern dark enough To mask thy monstrous visage? Seek none, conspiracy. Hide it in smiles and affability; For if thou path, thy native semblance on, Not Erebus itself were dim enough To hide thee from prevention. Enter the conspirators, Cassius, Casca, Decius, Cinna, Metellus, and Trebonius.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: I think we are too bold upon your rest. Good morrow, Brutus. Do we trouble you?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: I have been up this hour, awake all night. Know I these men that come along with you?

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Yes, every man of them; and no man here But honors you, and every one doth wish You had but that opinion of yourself Which every noble Roman bears of you. This is Trebonius.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: He is welcome hither.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: This, Decius Brutus.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: He is welcome too.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: This, Casca; this, Cinna; and this, Metellus Cimber.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: They are all welcome. What watchful cares do interpose themselves Betwixt your eyes and night?

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Shall I entreat a word? Brutus and Cassius whisper.

speaker: DECIUS
text: Here lies the east; doth not the day break here?

speaker: CASCA
text: No.

speaker: CINNA
text: O pardon, sir, it doth; and yon gray lines That fret the clouds are messengers of day.

speaker: CASCA
text: You shall confess that you are both deceived. Here, as I point my sword, the sun arises, Which is a great way growing on the south, Weighing the youthful season of the year. Some two months hence, up higher toward the north He first presents his fire, and the high east Stands, as the Capitol, directly here. BRUTUS, coming forward with Cassius Give me your hands all over, one by one.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: And let us swear our resolution.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: No, not an oath. If not the face of men, The sufferance of our souls, the time’s abuse— If these be motives weak, break off betimes, And every man hence to his idle bed. So let high-sighted tyranny range on

speaker: CASSIUS
text: But what of Cicero? Shall we sound him? I think he will stand very strong with us.

speaker: CASCA
text: Let us not leave him out.

speaker: CINNA
text: No, by no means.

speaker: METELLUS
text: O, let us have him, for his silver hairs Will purchase us a good opinion And buy men’s voices to commend our deeds. It shall be said his judgment ruled our hands. Our youths and wildness shall no whit appear, But all be buried in his gravity.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: O, name him not! Let us not break with him, For he will never follow anything That other men begin.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Then leave him out.

speaker: CASCA
text: Indeed, he is not fit.

speaker: DECIUS
text: Shall no man else be touched, but only Caesar?

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Decius, well urged. I think it is not meet Mark Antony, so well beloved of Caesar, Should outlive Caesar. We shall find of him A shrewd contriver; and, you know, his means, If he improve them, may well stretch so far As to annoy us all; which to prevent, Let Antony and Caesar fall together.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Our course will seem too bloody, Caius Cassius, To cut the head off and then hack the limbs, Like wrath in death and envy afterwards; For Antony is but a limb of Caesar. Let’s be sacrificers, but not butchers, Caius. We all stand up against the spirit of Caesar, And in the spirit of men there is no blood. O, that we then could come by Caesar’s spirit And not dismember Caesar! But, alas, Caesar must bleed for it. And, gentle friends, Let’s kill him boldly, but not wrathfully. Let’s carve him as a dish fit for the gods, Not hew him as a carcass fit for hounds. And let our hearts, as subtle masters do, Stir up their servants to an act of rage And after seem to chide ’em. This shall make Our purpose necessary and not envious; Which so appearing to the common eyes, We shall be called purgers, not murderers.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Yet I fear him, For in the engrafted love he bears to Caesar—

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Alas, good Cassius, do not think of him. If he love Caesar, all that he can do Is to himself: take thought and die for Caesar. And that were much he should, for he is given To sports, to wildness, and much company.

speaker: TREBONIUS
text: There is no fear in him. Let him not die, For he will live and laugh at this hereafter. Clock strikes.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Peace, count the clock.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: The clock hath stricken three.

speaker: TREBONIUS
text: ’Tis time to part.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: But it is doubtful yet Whether Caesar will come forth today or no, For he is superstitious grown of late, Quite from the main opinion he held once Of fantasy, of dreams, and ceremonies. It may be these apparent prodigies, The unaccustomed terror of this night, And the persuasion of his augurers May hold him from the Capitol today.

speaker: DECIUS
text: Never fear that. If he be so resolved, I can o’ersway him, for he loves to hear That unicorns may be betrayed with trees, And bears with glasses, elephants with holes, Lions with toils, and men with flatterers.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Nay, we will all of us be there to fetch him.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: By the eighth hour, is that the uttermost?

speaker: CINNA
text: Be that the uttermost, and fail not then.

speaker: METELLUS
text: Caius Ligarius doth bear Caesar hard, Who rated him for speaking well of Pompey. I wonder none of you have thought of him.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Now, good Metellus, go along by him. He loves me well, and I have given him reasons. Send him but hither, and I’ll fashion him.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: The morning comes upon ’s. We’ll leave you, Brutus. And, friends, disperse yourselves, but all remember What you have said, and show yourselves true Romans.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Good gentlemen, look fresh and merrily. Let not our looks put on our purposes, But bear it, as our Roman actors do, With untired spirits and formal constancy. And so good morrow to you every one. All but Brutus exit. Boy! Lucius!—Fast asleep? It is no matter. Enjoy the honey-heavy dew of slumber. Thou hast no figures nor no fantasies

speaker: PORTIA
text: Brutus, my lord.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Portia! What mean you? Wherefore rise you now? It is not for your health thus to commit Your weak condition to the raw cold morning.

speaker: PORTIA
text: Nor for yours neither. You’ve ungently, Brutus, Stole from my bed. And yesternight at supper You suddenly arose and walked about, Musing and sighing, with your arms across, And when I asked you what the matter was, You stared upon me with ungentle looks. I urged you further; then you scratched your head And too impatiently stamped with your foot. Yet I insisted; yet you answered not, But with an angry wafture of your hand Gave sign for me to leave you. So I did, Fearing to strengthen that impatience Which seemed too much enkindled, and withal Hoping it was but an effect of humor, Which sometime hath his hour with every man. It will not let you eat nor talk nor sleep, And could it work so much upon your shape As it hath much prevailed on your condition, I should not know you Brutus. Dear my lord, Make me acquainted with your cause of grief.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: I am not well in health, and that is all.

speaker: PORTIA
text: Brutus is wise and, were he not in health, He would embrace the means to come by it.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Why so I do. Good Portia, go to bed.

speaker: PORTIA
text: Is Brutus sick? And is it physical To walk unbracèd and suck up the humors Of the dank morning? What, is Brutus sick, And will he steal out of his wholesome bed To dare the vile contagion of the night And tempt the rheumy and unpurgèd air To add unto his sickness? No, my Brutus, You have some sick offense within your mind, Which by the right and virtue of my place I ought to know of. She kneels. And upon my knees I charm you, by my once commended beauty, By all your vows of love, and that great vow Which did incorporate and make us one, That you unfold to me, your self, your half, Why you are heavy, and what men tonight Have had resort to you; for here have been Some six or seven who did hide their faces Even from darkness.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Kneel not, gentle Portia. He lifts her up.

speaker: PORTIA
text: I should not need, if you were gentle Brutus. Within the bond of marriage, tell me, Brutus, Is it excepted I should know no secrets That appertain to you? Am I your self But, as it were, in sort or limitation, To keep with you at meals, comfort your bed, And talk to you sometimes? Dwell I but in the suburbs Of your good pleasure? If it be no more, Portia is Brutus’ harlot, not his wife.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: You are my true and honorable wife, As dear to me as are the ruddy drops That visit my sad heart.

speaker: PORTIA
text: If this were true, then should I know this secret. I grant I am a woman, but withal A woman that Lord Brutus took to wife. I grant I am a woman, but withal A woman well-reputed, Cato’s daughter. Think you I am no stronger than my sex, Being so fathered and so husbanded? Tell me your counsels; I will not disclose ’em. I have made strong proof of my constancy, Giving myself a voluntary wound Here, in the thigh. Can I bear that with patience, And not my husband’s secrets?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: O you gods, Render me worthy of this noble wife! Knock. Hark, hark, one knocks. Portia, go in awhile, And by and by thy bosom shall partake The secrets of my heart. All my engagements I will construe to thee, All the charactery of my sad brows. Leave me with haste. Portia exits. Lucius, who ’s that knocks? Enter Lucius and Ligarius.

speaker: LUCIUS
text: Here is a sick man that would speak with you.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Caius Ligarius, that Metellus spoke of.— Boy, stand aside. Lucius exits. Caius Ligarius, how?

speaker: LIGARIUS
text: Vouchsafe good morrow from a feeble tongue.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: O, what a time have you chose out, brave Caius, To wear a kerchief! Would you were not sick!

speaker: LIGARIUS
text: I am not sick, if Brutus have in hand Any exploit worthy the name of honor.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Such an exploit have I in hand, Ligarius, Had you a healthful ear to hear of it.

speaker: LIGARIUS
text: By all the gods that Romans bow before, I here discard my sickness. He takes off his kerchief. Soul of Rome, Brave son derived from honorable loins, Thou like an exorcist hast conjured up My mortifièd spirit. Now bid me run, And I will strive with things impossible, Yea, get the better of them. What’s to do?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: A piece of work that will make sick men whole.

speaker: LIGARIUS
text: But are not some whole that we must make sick?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: That must we also. What it is, my Caius, I shall unfold to thee as we are going To whom it must be done.

speaker: LIGARIUS
text: Set on your foot, And with a heart new-fired I follow you To do I know not what; but it sufficeth That Brutus leads me on. Thunder.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Follow me then. They exit.

speaker: CAESAR
text: Nor heaven nor Earth have been at peace tonight. Thrice hath Calphurnia in her sleep cried out “Help ho, they murder Caesar!”—Who’s within? Enter a Servant.

speaker: SERVANT
text: My lord.

speaker: CAESAR
text: Go bid the priests do present sacrifice, And bring me their opinions of success.

speaker: SERVANT
text: I will, my lord. He exits. Enter Calphurnia.

speaker: CALPHURNIA
text: What mean you, Caesar? Think you to walk forth? You shall not stir out of your house today.

speaker: CAESAR
text: Caesar shall forth. The things that threatened me Ne’er looked but on my back. When they shall see The face of Caesar, they are vanishèd.

speaker: CALPHURNIA
text: Caesar, I never stood on ceremonies, Yet now they fright me. There is one within, Besides the things that we have heard and seen, Recounts most horrid sights seen by the watch. A lioness hath whelpèd in the streets, And graves have yawned and yielded up their dead. Fierce fiery warriors fought upon the clouds In ranks and squadrons and right form of war, Which drizzled blood upon the Capitol. The noise of battle hurtled in the air, Horses did neigh, and dying men did groan,

speaker: CAESAR
text: What can be avoided Whose end is purposed by the mighty gods? Yet Caesar shall go forth, for these predictions Are to the world in general as to Caesar.

speaker: CALPHURNIA
text: When beggars die there are no comets seen; The heavens themselves blaze forth the death of princes.

speaker: CAESAR
text: Cowards die many times before their deaths; The valiant never taste of death but once. Of all the wonders that I yet have heard, It seems to me most strange that men should fear, Seeing that death, a necessary end, Will come when it will come. Enter a Servant. What say the augurers?

speaker: SERVANT
text: They would not have you to stir forth today. Plucking the entrails of an offering forth, They could not find a heart within the beast.

speaker: CAESAR
text: The gods do this in shame of cowardice. Caesar should be a beast without a heart If he should stay at home today for fear. No, Caesar shall not. Danger knows full well That Caesar is more dangerous than he. We are two lions littered in one day, And I the elder and more terrible. And Caesar shall go forth.

speaker: CALPHURNIA
text: Alas, my lord, Your wisdom is consumed in confidence.

speaker: CAESAR
text: Mark Antony shall say I am not well, And for thy humor I will stay at home. He lifts her up. Enter Decius. Here’s Decius Brutus; he shall tell them so.

speaker: DECIUS
text: Caesar, all hail! Good morrow, worthy Caesar. I come to fetch you to the Senate House.

speaker: CAESAR
text: And you are come in very happy time To bear my greeting to the Senators And tell them that I will not come today. Cannot is false, and that I dare not, falser. I will not come today. Tell them so, Decius.

speaker: CALPHURNIA
text: Say he is sick.

speaker: CAESAR
text: Shall Caesar send a lie? Have I in conquest stretched mine arm so far, To be afeard to tell graybeards the truth? Decius, go tell them Caesar will not come.

speaker: DECIUS
text: Most mighty Caesar, let me know some cause, Lest I be laughed at when I tell them so.

speaker: CAESAR
text: The cause is in my will. I will not come. That is enough to satisfy the Senate. But for your private satisfaction, Because I love you, I will let you know. Calphurnia here, my wife, stays me at home.

speaker: DECIUS
text: This dream is all amiss interpreted. It was a vision fair and fortunate. Your statue spouting blood in many pipes, In which so many smiling Romans bathed, Signifies that from you great Rome shall suck Reviving blood, and that great men shall press For tinctures, stains, relics, and cognizance. This by Calphurnia’s dream is signified.

speaker: CAESAR
text: And this way have you well expounded it.

speaker: DECIUS
text: I have, when you have heard what I can say. And know it now: the Senate have concluded To give this day a crown to mighty Caesar. If you shall send them word you will not come, Their minds may change. Besides, it were a mock Apt to be rendered, for someone to say “Break up the Senate till another time, When Caesar’s wife shall meet with better dreams.” If Caesar hide himself, shall they not whisper “Lo, Caesar is afraid”? Pardon me, Caesar, for my dear dear love To your proceeding bids me tell you this, And reason to my love is liable.

speaker: CAESAR
text: How foolish do your fears seem now, Calphurnia! I am ashamèd I did yield to them. Give me my robe, for I will go.

speaker: PUBLIUS
text: Good morrow, Caesar.

speaker: CAESAR
text: Welcome, Publius.— What, Brutus, are you stirred so early too?— Good morrow, Casca.—Caius Ligarius, Caesar was ne’er so much your enemy As that same ague which hath made you lean.— What is ’t o’clock?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Caesar, ’tis strucken eight.

speaker: CAESAR
text: I thank you for your pains and courtesy. Enter Antony. See, Antony that revels long a-nights Is notwithstanding up.—Good morrow, Antony.

speaker: ANTONY
text: So to most noble Caesar. CAESAR, to Servant Bid them prepare within.— I am to blame to be thus waited for. Servant exits. Now, Cinna.—Now, Metellus.—What, Trebonius, I have an hour’s talk in store for you. Remember that you call on me today; Be near me that I may remember you.

speaker: TREBONIUS
text: Caesar, I will. Aside. And so near will I be That your best friends shall wish I had been further.

speaker: CAESAR
text: Good friends, go in and taste some wine with me, And we, like friends, will straightway go together. BRUTUS, aside That every like is not the same, O Caesar, The heart of Brutus earns to think upon. They exit.

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text: Caesar, beware of Brutus, take heed of Cassius, come not near Casca, have an eye to Cinna, trust not Trebonius, mark well Metellus Cimber. Decius Brutus loves thee not. Thou hast wronged Caius Ligarius. There is but one mind in all these men, and it is bent against Caesar. If thou beest not immortal, look about you. Security gives way to conspiracy. The mighty gods defend thee! Thy lover, Artemidorus Here will I stand till Caesar pass along, And as a suitor will I give him this. My heart laments that virtue cannot live Out of the teeth of emulation. If thou read this, O Caesar, thou mayest live; If not, the Fates with traitors do contrive. He exits.

speaker: PORTIA
text: I prithee, boy, run to the Senate House. Stay not to answer me, but get thee gone. Why dost thou stay?

speaker: LUCIUS
text: To know my errand, madam.

speaker: PORTIA
text: I would have had thee there and here again Ere I can tell thee what thou shouldst do there. Aside. O constancy, be strong upon my side; Set a huge mountain ’tween my heart and tongue. I have a man’s mind but a woman’s might.

speaker: LUCIUS
text: Madam, what should I do? Run to the Capitol, and nothing else? And so return to you, and nothing else?

speaker: PORTIA
text: Yes, bring me word, boy, if thy lord look well, For he went sickly forth. And take good note What Caesar doth, what suitors press to him. Hark, boy, what noise is that?

speaker: LUCIUS
text: I hear none, madam.

speaker: PORTIA
text: Prithee, listen well. I heard a bustling rumor like a fray, And the wind brings it from the Capitol.

speaker: LUCIUS
text: Sooth, madam, I hear nothing. Enter the Soothsayer.

speaker: PORTIA
text: Come hither, fellow. Which way hast thou been?

speaker: SOOTHSAYER
text: At mine own house, good lady.

speaker: PORTIA
text: What is ’t o’clock?

speaker: SOOTHSAYER
text: About the ninth hour, lady.

speaker: PORTIA
text: Is Caesar yet gone to the Capitol?

speaker: SOOTHSAYER
text: Madam, not yet. I go to take my stand To see him pass on to the Capitol.

speaker: PORTIA
text: Thou hast some suit to Caesar, hast thou not?

speaker: SOOTHSAYER
text: That I have, lady. If it will please Caesar To be so good to Caesar as to hear me, I shall beseech him to befriend himself.

speaker: PORTIA
text: Why, know’st thou any harm’s intended towards him?

speaker: SOOTHSAYER
text: None that I know will be, much that I fear may chance. Good morrow to you.—Here the street is narrow. The throng that follows Caesar at the heels, Of senators, of praetors, common suitors, Will crowd a feeble man almost to death. I’ll get me to a place more void, and there Speak to great Caesar as he comes along. He exits.

speaker: PORTIA
text: I must go in. Aside. Ay me, how weak a thing The heart of woman is! O Brutus, The heavens speed thee in thine enterprise! Sure the boy heard me. To Lucius. Brutus hath a suit That Caesar will not grant. Aside. O, I grow faint.— Run, Lucius, and commend me to my lord. Say I am merry. Come to me again And bring me word what he doth say to thee. They exit separately.

speaker: CAESAR
text: The ides of March are come.

speaker: SOOTHSAYER
text: Ay, Caesar, but not gone.

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text: Hail, Caesar. Read this schedule.

speaker: DECIUS
text: Trebonius doth desire you to o’erread, At your best leisure, this his humble suit.

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text: O Caesar, read mine first, for mine’s a suit That touches Caesar nearer. Read it, great Caesar.

speaker: CAESAR
text: What touches us ourself shall be last served.

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text: Delay not, Caesar; read it instantly.

speaker: CAESAR
text: What, is the fellow mad?

speaker: PUBLIUS
text: Sirrah, give place.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: What, urge you your petitions in the street? Come to the Capitol. Caesar goes forward, the rest following.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: What enterprise, Popilius?

speaker: POPILIUS
text: Fare you well. He walks away.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: What said Popilius Lena?

speaker: CASSIUS
text: He wished today our enterprise might thrive. I fear our purpose is discoverèd.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Look how he makes to Caesar. Mark him.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Casca, be sudden, for we fear prevention.— Brutus, what shall be done? If this be known, Cassius or Caesar never shall turn back, For I will slay myself.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Cassius, be constant. Popilius Lena speaks not of our purposes, For look, he smiles, and Caesar doth not change.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Trebonius knows his time, for look you, Brutus, He draws Mark Antony out of the way. Trebonius and Antony exit.

speaker: DECIUS
text: Where is Metellus Cimber? Let him go And presently prefer his suit to Caesar.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: He is addressed. Press near and second him.

speaker: CINNA
text: Casca, you are the first that rears your hand.

speaker: CAESAR
text: Are we all ready? What is now amiss That Caesar and his Senate must redress? METELLUS, kneeling Most high, most mighty, and most puissant Caesar, Metellus Cimber throws before thy seat An humble heart.

speaker: CAESAR
text: I must prevent thee, Cimber. These couchings and these lowly courtesies Might fire the blood of ordinary men And turn preordinance and first decree Into the law of children. Be not fond To think that Caesar bears such rebel blood That will be thawed from the true quality With that which melteth fools—I mean sweet words, Low-crookèd curtsies, and base spaniel fawning. Thy brother by decree is banishèd. If thou dost bend and pray and fawn for him, I spurn thee like a cur out of my way. Know: Caesar doth not wrong, nor without cause Will he be satisfied.

speaker: METELLUS
text: Is there no voice more worthy than my own To sound more sweetly in great Caesar’s ear For the repealing of my banished brother? BRUTUS, kneeling I kiss thy hand, but not in flattery, Caesar, Desiring thee that Publius Cimber may Have an immediate freedom of repeal.

speaker: CAESAR
text: What, Brutus? CASSIUS, kneeling Pardon, Caesar; Caesar, pardon! As low as to thy foot doth Cassius fall To beg enfranchisement for Publius Cimber.

speaker: CAESAR
text: I could be well moved, if I were as you. If I could pray to move, prayers would move me. But I am constant as the Northern Star, Of whose true fixed and resting quality There is no fellow in the firmament. The skies are painted with unnumbered sparks;

speaker: CAESAR
text: Hence. Wilt thou lift up Olympus? DECIUS, kneeling Great Caesar—

speaker: CAESAR
text: Doth not Brutus bootless kneel?

speaker: CASCA
text: Speak, hands, for me! As Casca strikes, the others rise up and stab Caesar.

speaker: CAESAR
text: Et tu, Brutè?—Then fall, Caesar. He dies.

speaker: CINNA
text: Liberty! Freedom! Tyranny is dead! Run hence, proclaim, cry it about the streets.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Some to the common pulpits and cry out “Liberty, freedom, and enfranchisement.”

speaker: BRUTUS
text: People and Senators, be not affrighted. Fly not; stand still. Ambition’s debt is paid.

speaker: CASCA
text: Go to the pulpit, Brutus.

speaker: DECIUS
text: And Cassius too.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Where’s Publius?

speaker: CINNA
text: Here, quite confounded with this mutiny.

speaker: METELLUS
text: Stand fast together, lest some friend of Caesar’s Should chance—

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Talk not of standing.—Publius, good cheer. There is no harm intended to your person, Nor to no Roman else. So tell them, Publius.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: And leave us, Publius, lest that the people, Rushing on us, should do your age some mischief.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Do so, and let no man abide this deed But we the doers. All but the Conspirators exit. Enter Trebonius.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Where is Antony?

speaker: TREBONIUS
text: Fled to his house amazed. Men, wives, and children stare, cry out, and run As it were doomsday.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Fates, we will know your pleasures. That we shall die we know; ’tis but the time, And drawing days out, that men stand upon.

speaker: CASCA
text: Why, he that cuts off twenty years of life Cuts off so many years of fearing death.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Grant that, and then is death a benefit. So are we Caesar’s friends, that have abridged His time of fearing death. Stoop, Romans, stoop, And let us bathe our hands in Caesar’s blood Up to the elbows and besmear our swords. Then walk we forth, even to the marketplace, And, waving our red weapons o’er our heads, Let’s all cry “Peace, freedom, and liberty!”

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Stoop then, and wash. They smear their hands and swords with Caesar’s blood. How many ages hence Shall this our lofty scene be acted over In states unborn and accents yet unknown!

speaker: BRUTUS
text: How many times shall Caesar bleed in sport, That now on Pompey’s basis lies along No worthier than the dust!

speaker: CASSIUS
text: So oft as that shall be, So often shall the knot of us be called The men that gave their country liberty.

speaker: DECIUS
text: What, shall we forth?

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Ay, every man away. Brutus shall lead, and we will grace his heels With the most boldest and best hearts of Rome. Enter a Servant.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Soft, who comes here? A friend of Antony’s. SERVANT, kneeling Thus, Brutus, did my master bid me kneel. Thus did Mark Antony bid me fall down, And, being prostrate, thus he bade me say: Brutus is noble, wise, valiant, and honest; Caesar was mighty, bold, royal, and loving. Say, I love Brutus, and I honor him; Say, I feared Caesar, honored him, and loved him. If Brutus will vouchsafe that Antony May safely come to him and be resolved How Caesar hath deserved to lie in death, Mark Antony shall not love Caesar dead So well as Brutus living, but will follow The fortunes and affairs of noble Brutus

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Thy master is a wise and valiant Roman. I never thought him worse. Tell him, so please him come unto this place, He shall be satisfied and, by my honor, Depart untouched.

speaker: SERVANT
text: I’ll fetch him presently. Servant exits.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: I know that we shall have him well to friend.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: I wish we may; but yet have I a mind That fears him much, and my misgiving still Falls shrewdly to the purpose. Enter Antony.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: But here comes Antony.—Welcome, Mark Antony!

speaker: ANTONY
text: O mighty Caesar, dost thou lie so low? Are all thy conquests, glories, triumphs, spoils Shrunk to this little measure? Fare thee well.— I know not, gentlemen, what you intend, Who else must be let blood, who else is rank. If I myself, there is no hour so fit As Caesar’s death’s hour, nor no instrument Of half that worth as those your swords made rich With the most noble blood of all this world. I do beseech you, if you bear me hard, Now, whilst your purpled hands do reek and smoke, Fulfill your pleasure. Live a thousand years, I shall not find myself so apt to die; No place will please me so, no mean of death,

speaker: BRUTUS
text: O Antony, beg not your death of us! Though now we must appear bloody and cruel, As by our hands and this our present act You see we do, yet see you but our hands And this the bleeding business they have done. Our hearts you see not; they are pitiful; And pity to the general wrong of Rome (As fire drives out fire, so pity pity) Hath done this deed on Caesar. For your part, To you our swords have leaden points, Mark Antony. Our arms in strength of malice, and our hearts Of brothers’ temper, do receive you in With all kind love, good thoughts, and reverence.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Your voice shall be as strong as any man’s In the disposing of new dignities.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Only be patient till we have appeased The multitude, beside themselves with fear; And then we will deliver you the cause Why I, that did love Caesar when I struck him, Have thus proceeded.

speaker: ANTONY
text: I doubt not of your wisdom. Let each man render me his bloody hand. First, Marcus Brutus, will I shake with you.— Next, Caius Cassius, do I take your hand.— Now, Decius Brutus, yours;—now yours, Metellus;— Yours, Cinna;—and, my valiant Casca, yours;— Though last, not least in love, yours, good Trebonius.— Gentlemen all—alas, what shall I say? My credit now stands on such slippery ground That one of two bad ways you must conceit me,

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Mark Antony—

speaker: ANTONY
text: Pardon me, Caius Cassius. The enemies of Caesar shall say this; Then, in a friend, it is cold modesty.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: I blame you not for praising Caesar so. But what compact mean you to have with us? Will you be pricked in number of our friends, Or shall we on and not depend on you?

speaker: ANTONY
text: Therefore I took your hands, but was indeed Swayed from the point by looking down on Caesar. Friends am I with you all and love you all, Upon this hope, that you shall give me reasons Why and wherein Caesar was dangerous.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Or else were this a savage spectacle.

speaker: ANTONY
text: That’s all I seek; And am, moreover, suitor that I may Produce his body to the marketplace, And in the pulpit, as becomes a friend, Speak in the order of his funeral.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: You shall, Mark Antony.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Brutus, a word with you. Aside to Brutus. You know not what you do. Do not consent That Antony speak in his funeral. Know you how much the people may be moved By that which he will utter? BRUTUS, aside to Cassius By your pardon, I will myself into the pulpit first And show the reason of our Caesar’s death. What Antony shall speak I will protest He speaks by leave and by permission, And that we are contented Caesar shall Have all true rites and lawful ceremonies. It shall advantage more than do us wrong. CASSIUS, aside to Brutus I know not what may fall. I like it not.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Mark Antony, here, take you Caesar’s body. You shall not in your funeral speech blame us But speak all good you can devise of Caesar And say you do ’t by our permission, Else shall you not have any hand at all About his funeral. And you shall speak In the same pulpit whereto I am going, After my speech is ended.

speaker: ANTONY
text: Be it so. I do desire no more.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Prepare the body, then, and follow us. All but Antony exit.

speaker: ANTONY
text: O pardon me, thou bleeding piece of earth, That I am meek and gentle with these butchers. Thou art the ruins of the noblest man That ever livèd in the tide of times. Woe to the hand that shed this costly blood! Over thy wounds now do I prophesy (Which like dumb mouths do ope their ruby lips To beg the voice and utterance of my tongue) A curse shall light upon the limbs of men; Domestic fury and fierce civil strife Shall cumber all the parts of Italy; Blood and destruction shall be so in use And dreadful objects so familiar That mothers shall but smile when they behold Their infants quartered with the hands of war, All pity choked with custom of fell deeds; And Caesar’s spirit, ranging for revenge, With Ate by his side come hot from hell, Shall in these confines with a monarch’s voice Cry “Havoc!” and let slip the dogs of war, That this foul deed shall smell above the earth With carrion men groaning for burial. Enter Octavius’ Servant. You serve Octavius Caesar, do you not?

speaker: SERVANT
text: I do, Mark Antony.

speaker: ANTONY
text: Caesar did write for him to come to Rome.

speaker: SERVANT
text: He did receive his letters and is coming,

speaker: ANTONY
text: Thy heart is big. Get thee apart and weep. Passion, I see, is catching, for mine eyes, Seeing those beads of sorrow stand in thine, Began to water. Is thy master coming?

speaker: SERVANT
text: He lies tonight within seven leagues of Rome.

speaker: ANTONY
text: Post back with speed and tell him what hath chanced. Here is a mourning Rome, a dangerous Rome, No Rome of safety for Octavius yet. Hie hence and tell him so.—Yet stay awhile; Thou shalt not back till I have borne this corpse Into the marketplace. There shall I try, In my oration, how the people take The cruel issue of these bloody men, According to the which thou shalt discourse To young Octavius of the state of things. Lend me your hand. They exit with Caesar’s body.

speaker: PLEBEIANS
text: We will be satisfied! Let us be satisfied!

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Then follow me and give me audience, friends.— Cassius, go you into the other street And part the numbers.— Those that will hear me speak, let ’em stay here; Those that will follow Cassius, go with him;

speaker: SECOND PLEBEIAN
text: I will hear Cassius, and compare their reasons When severally we hear them renderèd. Cassius exits with some of the Plebeians. Brutus goes into the pulpit.

speaker: THIRD PLEBEIAN
text: The noble Brutus is ascended. Silence.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Be patient till the last. Romans, countrymen, and lovers, hear me for my cause, and be silent that you may hear. Believe me for mine honor, and have respect to mine honor that you may believe. Censure me in your wisdom, and awake your senses that you may the better judge. If there be any in this assembly, any dear friend of Caesar’s, to him I say that Brutus’ love to Caesar was no less than his. If then that friend demand why Brutus rose against Caesar, this is my answer: not that I loved Caesar less, but that I loved Rome more. Had you rather Caesar were living, and die all slaves, than that Caesar were dead, to live all freemen? As Caesar loved me, I weep for him. As he was fortunate, I rejoice at it. As he was valiant, I honor him. But, as he was ambitious, I slew him. There is tears for his love, joy for his fortune, honor for his valor, and death for his ambition. Who is here so base that would be a bondman? If any, speak, for him have I offended. Who is here so rude that would not be a Roman? If any, speak, for him have I offended. Who is here so vile that will not love his country? If any, speak, for him have I offended. I pause for a reply.

speaker: PLEBEIANS
text: None, Brutus, none.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Then none have I offended. I have done no

speaker: PLEBEIANS
text: Live, Brutus, live, live!

speaker: FIRST PLEBEIAN
text: Bring him with triumph home unto his house.

speaker: SECOND PLEBEIAN
text: Give him a statue with his ancestors.

speaker: THIRD PLEBEIAN
text: Let him be Caesar.

speaker: FOURTH PLEBEIAN
text: Caesar’s better parts Shall be crowned in Brutus.

speaker: FIRST PLEBEIAN
text: We’ll bring him to his house with shouts and clamors.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: My countrymen—

speaker: SECOND PLEBEIAN
text: Peace, silence! Brutus speaks.

speaker: FIRST PLEBEIAN
text: Peace, ho!

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Good countrymen, let me depart alone, And, for my sake, stay here with Antony. Do grace to Caesar’s corpse, and grace his speech Tending to Caesar’s glories, which Mark Antony (By our permission) is allowed to make.

speaker: FIRST PLEBEIAN
text: Stay, ho, and let us hear Mark Antony!

speaker: THIRD PLEBEIAN
text: Let him go up into the public chair.

speaker: PLEBEIANS
text: We’ll hear him.—Noble Antony, go up.

speaker: ANTONY
text: For Brutus’ sake, I am beholding to you. He goes into the pulpit.

speaker: FOURTH PLEBEIAN
text: What does he say of Brutus?

speaker: THIRD PLEBEIAN
text: He says for Brutus’ sake He finds himself beholding to us all.

speaker: FOURTH PLEBEIAN
text: ’Twere best he speak no harm of Brutus here.

speaker: FIRST PLEBEIAN
text: This Caesar was a tyrant.

speaker: THIRD PLEBEIAN
text: Nay, that’s certain. We are blest that Rome is rid of him.

speaker: SECOND PLEBEIAN
text: Peace, let us hear what Antony can say.

speaker: ANTONY
text: You gentle Romans—

speaker: PLEBEIANS
text: Peace, ho! Let us hear him.

speaker: ANTONY
text: Friends, Romans, countrymen, lend me your ears. I come to bury Caesar, not to praise him. The evil that men do lives after them; The good is oft interrèd with their bones. So let it be with Caesar. The noble Brutus Hath told you Caesar was ambitious. If it were so, it was a grievous fault, And grievously hath Caesar answered it. Here, under leave of Brutus and the rest (For Brutus is an honorable man;

speaker: FIRST PLEBEIAN
text: Methinks there is much reason in his sayings.

speaker: SECOND PLEBEIAN
text: If thou consider rightly of the matter, Caesar has had great wrong.

speaker: THIRD PLEBEIAN
text: Has he, masters? I fear there will a worse come in his place.

speaker: FOURTH PLEBEIAN
text: Marked you his words? He would not take the crown; Therefore ’tis certain he was not ambitious.

speaker: FIRST PLEBEIAN
text: If it be found so, some will dear abide it.

speaker: SECOND PLEBEIAN
text: Poor soul, his eyes are red as fire with weeping.

speaker: THIRD PLEBEIAN
text: There’s not a nobler man in Rome than Antony.

speaker: FOURTH PLEBEIAN
text: Now mark him. He begins again to speak.

speaker: ANTONY
text: But yesterday the word of Caesar might Have stood against the world. Now lies he there, And none so poor to do him reverence. O masters, if I were disposed to stir Your hearts and minds to mutiny and rage, I should do Brutus wrong and Cassius wrong, Who, you all know, are honorable men. I will not do them wrong. I rather choose To wrong the dead, to wrong myself and you, Than I will wrong such honorable men. But here’s a parchment with the seal of Caesar. I found it in his closet. ’Tis his will. Let but the commons hear this testament, Which, pardon me, I do not mean to read, And they would go and kiss dead Caesar’s wounds And dip their napkins in his sacred blood— Yea, beg a hair of him for memory And, dying, mention it within their wills, Bequeathing it as a rich legacy Unto their issue.

speaker: FOURTH PLEBEIAN
text: We’ll hear the will. Read it, Mark Antony.

speaker: PLEBEIANS
text: The will, the will! We will hear Caesar’s will.

speaker: ANTONY
text: Have patience, gentle friends. I must not read it.

speaker: FOURTH PLEBEIAN
text: Read the will! We’ll hear it, Antony.

speaker: PLEBEIANS
text: You shall read us the will, Caesar’s will.

speaker: ANTONY
text: Will you be patient? Will you stay awhile? I have o’ershot myself to tell you of it. I fear I wrong the honorable men Whose daggers have stabbed Caesar. I do fear it.

speaker: FOURTH PLEBEIAN
text: They were traitors. Honorable men?

speaker: PLEBEIANS
text: The will! The testament!

speaker: SECOND PLEBEIAN
text: They were villains, murderers. The will! Read the will.

speaker: ANTONY
text: You will compel me, then, to read the will? Then make a ring about the corpse of Caesar, And let me show you him that made the will. Shall I descend? And will you give me leave?

speaker: PLEBEIANS
text: Come down.

speaker: SECOND PLEBEIAN
text: Descend.

speaker: THIRD PLEBEIAN
text: You shall have leave. Antony descends. FOURTH PLEBEIAN A ring; stand round.

speaker: FIRST PLEBEIAN
text: Stand from the hearse. Stand from the body.

speaker: SECOND PLEBEIAN
text: Room for Antony, most noble Antony.

speaker: ANTONY
text: Nay, press not so upon me. Stand far off.

speaker: PLEBEIANS
text: Stand back! Room! Bear back!

speaker: ANTONY
text: If you have tears, prepare to shed them now. You all do know this mantle. I remember The first time ever Caesar put it on. ’Twas on a summer’s evening in his tent, That day he overcame the Nervii. Look, in this place ran Cassius’ dagger through. See what a rent the envious Casca made. Through this the well-belovèd Brutus stabbed, And, as he plucked his cursèd steel away, Mark how the blood of Caesar followed it, As rushing out of doors to be resolved If Brutus so unkindly knocked or no; For Brutus, as you know, was Caesar’s angel. Judge, O you gods, how dearly Caesar loved him! This was the most unkindest cut of all. For when the noble Caesar saw him stab, Ingratitude, more strong than traitors’ arms, Quite vanquished him. Then burst his mighty heart, And, in his mantle muffling up his face, Even at the base of Pompey’s statue (Which all the while ran blood) great Caesar fell. O, what a fall was there, my countrymen! Then I and you and all of us fell down, Whilst bloody treason flourished over us. O, now you weep, and I perceive you feel The dint of pity. These are gracious drops. Kind souls, what, weep you when you but behold Our Caesar’s vesture wounded? Look you here, Antony lifts Caesar’s cloak. Here is himself, marred as you see with traitors. FIRST PLEBEIAN O piteous spectacle! SECOND PLEBEIAN O noble Caesar! THIRD PLEBEIAN O woeful day!

speaker: SECOND PLEBEIAN
text: We will be revenged.

speaker: PLEBEIANS
text: Revenge! About! Seek! Burn! Fire! Kill! Slay! Let not a traitor live!

speaker: ANTONY
text: Stay, countrymen.

speaker: FIRST PLEBEIAN
text: Peace there! Hear the noble Antony.

speaker: SECOND PLEBEIAN
text: We’ll hear him, we’ll follow him, we’ll die with him.

speaker: ANTONY
text: Good friends, sweet friends, let me not stir you up To such a sudden flood of mutiny. They that have done this deed are honorable. What private griefs they have, alas, I know not, That made them do it. They are wise and honorable And will no doubt with reasons answer you. I come not, friends, to steal away your hearts. I am no orator, as Brutus is, But, as you know me all, a plain blunt man That love my friend, and that they know full well That gave me public leave to speak of him. For I have neither wit, nor words, nor worth, Action, nor utterance, nor the power of speech To stir men’s blood. I only speak right on. I tell you that which you yourselves do know, Show you sweet Caesar’s wounds, poor poor dumb mouths, And bid them speak for me. But were I Brutus, And Brutus Antony, there were an Antony Would ruffle up your spirits and put a tongue In every wound of Caesar that should move The stones of Rome to rise and mutiny.

speaker: PLEBEIANS
text: We’ll mutiny.

speaker: FIRST PLEBEIAN
text: We’ll burn the house of Brutus.

speaker: THIRD PLEBEIAN
text: Away then. Come, seek the conspirators.

speaker: ANTONY
text: Yet hear me, countrymen; yet hear me speak.

speaker: PLEBEIANS
text: Peace, ho! Hear Antony, most noble Antony!

speaker: ANTONY
text: Why, friends, you go to do you know not what. Wherein hath Caesar thus deserved your loves? Alas, you know not. I must tell you then. You have forgot the will I told you of.

speaker: PLEBEIANS
text: Most true. The will! Let’s stay and hear the will.

speaker: ANTONY
text: Here is the will, and under Caesar’s seal: To every Roman citizen he gives, To every several man, seventy-five drachmas.

speaker: SECOND PLEBEIAN
text: Most noble Caesar! We’ll revenge his death. THIRD PLEBEIAN O royal Caesar!

speaker: ANTONY
text: Hear me with patience.

speaker: PLEBEIANS
text: Peace, ho!

speaker: ANTONY
text: Moreover, he hath left you all his walks, His private arbors, and new-planted orchards, On this side Tiber. He hath left them you, And to your heirs forever—common pleasures To walk abroad and recreate yourselves. Here was a Caesar! When comes such another?

speaker: FIRST PLEBEIAN
text: Never, never!—Come, away, away! We’ll burn his body in the holy place And with the brands fire the traitors’ houses. Take up the body.

speaker: SECOND PLEBEIAN
text: Go fetch fire.

speaker: THIRD PLEBEIAN
text: Pluck down benches.

speaker: FOURTH PLEBEIAN
text: Pluck down forms, windows, anything. Plebeians exit with Caesar’s body.

speaker: ANTONY
text: Now let it work. Mischief, thou art afoot; Take thou what course thou wilt. Enter Servant. How now, fellow?

speaker: SERVANT
text: Sir, Octavius is already come to Rome.

speaker: ANTONY
text: Where is he?

speaker: SERVANT
text: He and Lepidus are at Caesar’s house.

speaker: ANTONY
text: And thither will I straight to visit him. He comes upon a wish. Fortune is merry And in this mood will give us anything.

speaker: SERVANT
text: I heard him say Brutus and Cassius Are rid like madmen through the gates of Rome.

speaker: ANTONY
text: Belike they had some notice of the people How I had moved them. Bring me to Octavius. They exit.

speaker: CINNA
text: I dreamt tonight that I did feast with Caesar, And things unluckily charge my fantasy. I have no will to wander forth of doors, Yet something leads me forth.

speaker: FIRST PLEBEIAN
text: What is your name?

speaker: SECOND PLEBEIAN
text: Whither are you going?

speaker: THIRD PLEBEIAN
text: Where do you dwell?

speaker: FOURTH PLEBEIAN
text: Are you a married man or a bachelor?

speaker: SECOND PLEBEIAN
text: Answer every man directly.

speaker: FIRST PLEBEIAN
text: Ay, and briefly.

speaker: FOURTH PLEBEIAN
text: Ay, and wisely.

speaker: THIRD PLEBEIAN
text: Ay, and truly, you were best.

speaker: CINNA
text: What is my name? Whither am I going? Where do I dwell? Am I a married man or a bachelor? Then to answer every man directly and briefly, wisely and truly: wisely I say, I am a bachelor.

speaker: SECOND PLEBEIAN
text: That’s as much as to say they are fools that marry. You’ll bear me a bang for that, I fear. Proceed directly.

speaker: CINNA
text: Directly, I am going to Caesar’s funeral.

speaker: FIRST PLEBEIAN
text: As a friend or an enemy?

speaker: CINNA
text: As a friend.

speaker: SECOND PLEBEIAN
text: That matter is answered directly.

speaker: FOURTH PLEBEIAN
text: For your dwelling—briefly.

speaker: CINNA
text: Briefly, I dwell by the Capitol.

speaker: THIRD PLEBEIAN
text: Your name, sir, truly.

speaker: CINNA
text: Truly, my name is Cinna.

speaker: FIRST PLEBEIAN
text: Tear him to pieces! He’s a conspirator.

speaker: CINNA
text: I am Cinna the poet, I am Cinna the poet!

speaker: FOURTH PLEBEIAN
text: Tear him for his bad verses, tear him for his bad verses!

speaker: CINNA
text: I am not Cinna the conspirator.

speaker: FOURTH PLEBEIAN
text: It is no matter. His name’s Cinna. Pluck but his name out of his heart, and turn him going.

speaker: THIRD PLEBEIAN
text: Tear him, tear him! Come, brands, ho, firebrands! To Brutus’, to Cassius’, burn all! Some to Decius’ house, and some to Casca’s, some to Ligarius’. Away, go! All the Plebeians exit, carrying off Cinna.

speaker: ANTONY
text: These many, then, shall die; their names are pricked.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text: Your brother too must die. Consent you, Lepidus?

speaker: LEPIDUS
text: I do consent.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text: Prick him down, Antony.

speaker: LEPIDUS
text: Upon condition Publius shall not live, Who is your sister’s son, Mark Antony.

speaker: ANTONY
text: He shall not live; look, with a spot I damn him. But, Lepidus, go you to Caesar’s house; Fetch the will hither, and we shall determine How to cut off some charge in legacies.

speaker: LEPIDUS
text: What, shall I find you here?

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text: Or here, or at the Capitol. Lepidus exits.

speaker: ANTONY
text: This is a slight, unmeritable man, Meet to be sent on errands. Is it fit, The threefold world divided, he should stand One of the three to share it?

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text: So you thought him And took his voice who should be pricked to die In our black sentence and proscription.

speaker: ANTONY
text: Octavius, I have seen more days than you, And, though we lay these honors on this man To ease ourselves of diverse sland’rous loads, He shall but bear them as the ass bears gold, To groan and sweat under the business, Either led or driven, as we point the way; And having brought our treasure where we will, Then take we down his load and turn him off (Like to the empty ass) to shake his ears And graze in commons.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text: You may do your will, But he’s a tried and valiant soldier.

speaker: ANTONY
text: So is my horse, Octavius, and for that I do appoint him store of provender. It is a creature that I teach to fight, To wind, to stop, to run directly on, His corporal motion governed by my spirit; And, in some taste, is Lepidus but so. He must be taught and trained and bid go forth— A barren-spirited fellow, one that feeds On objects, arts, and imitations Which, out of use and staled by other men, Begin his fashion. Do not talk of him But as a property. And now, Octavius, Listen great things. Brutus and Cassius Are levying powers. We must straight make head. Therefore let our alliance be combined, Our best friends made, our means stretched; And let us presently go sit in council How covert matters may be best disclosed And open perils surest answerèd.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text: Let us do so, for we are at the stake And bayed about with many enemies, And some that smile have in their hearts, I fear, Millions of mischiefs. They exit.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Stand ho!

speaker: LUCILIUS
text: Give the word, ho, and stand!

speaker: BRUTUS
text: What now, Lucilius, is Cassius near?

speaker: LUCILIUS
text: He is at hand, and Pindarus is come To do you salutation from his master.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: He greets me well.—Your master, Pindarus, In his own change or by ill officers, Hath given me some worthy cause to wish Things done undone, but if he be at hand I shall be satisfied.

speaker: PINDARUS
text: I do not doubt But that my noble master will appear Such as he is, full of regard and honor.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: He is not doubted. Brutus and Lucilius walk aside. A word, Lucilius, How he received you. Let me be resolved.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text: With courtesy and with respect enough, But not with such familiar instances Nor with such free and friendly conference As he hath used of old.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Thou hast described A hot friend cooling. Ever note, Lucilius, When love begins to sicken and decay It useth an enforcèd ceremony. There are no tricks in plain and simple faith; But hollow men, like horses hot at hand, Make gallant show and promise of their mettle, Low march within. But when they should endure the bloody spur, They fall their crests and, like deceitful jades, Sink in the trial. Comes his army on?

speaker: LUCILIUS
text: They mean this night in Sardis to be quartered. The greater part, the horse in general, Are come with Cassius. Enter Cassius and his powers.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Hark, he is arrived. March gently on to meet him.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Stand ho!

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Stand ho! Speak the word along.

speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
text: Stand!

speaker: SECOND SOLDIER
text: Stand!

speaker: THIRD SOLDIER
text: Stand!

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Most noble brother, you have done me wrong.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Judge me, you gods! Wrong I mine enemies? And if not so, how should I wrong a brother?

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Brutus, this sober form of yours hides wrongs, And when you do them—

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Cassius, be content. Speak your griefs softly. I do know you well. Before the eyes of both our armies here (Which should perceive nothing but love from us),

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Pindarus, Bid our commanders lead their charges off A little from this ground.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Lucius, do you the like, and let no man Come to our tent till we have done our conference. Let Lucilius and Titinius guard our door. All but Brutus and Cassius exit.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: That you have wronged me doth appear in this: You have condemned and noted Lucius Pella For taking bribes here of the Sardians, Wherein my letters, praying on his side Because I knew the man, was slighted off.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: You wronged yourself to write in such a case.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: In such a time as this it is not meet That every nice offense should bear his comment.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Let me tell you, Cassius, you yourself Are much condemned to have an itching palm, To sell and mart your offices for gold To undeservers.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: I an itching palm? You know that you are Brutus that speaks this, Or, by the gods, this speech were else your last.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: The name of Cassius honors this corruption, And chastisement doth therefore hide his head.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Chastisement?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Remember March; the ides of March remember. Did not great Julius bleed for justice’ sake? What villain touched his body that did stab And not for justice? What, shall one of us That struck the foremost man of all this world But for supporting robbers, shall we now Contaminate our fingers with base bribes And sell the mighty space of our large honors For so much trash as may be graspèd thus? I had rather be a dog and bay the moon Than such a Roman.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Brutus, bait not me. I’ll not endure it. You forget yourself To hedge me in. I am a soldier, I, Older in practice, abler than yourself To make conditions.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Go to! You are not, Cassius.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: I am.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: I say you are not.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Urge me no more. I shall forget myself. Have mind upon your health. Tempt me no farther.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Away, slight man!

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Is ’t possible?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Hear me, for I will speak. Must I give way and room to your rash choler? Shall I be frighted when a madman stares?

speaker: CASSIUS
text: O you gods, you gods, must I endure all this?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: All this? Ay, more. Fret till your proud heart break. Go show your slaves how choleric you are And make your bondmen tremble. Must I budge?

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Is it come to this?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: You say you are a better soldier. Let it appear so, make your vaunting true, And it shall please me well. For mine own part, I shall be glad to learn of noble men.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: You wrong me every way, you wrong me, Brutus. I said an elder soldier, not a better. Did I say “better”?

speaker: BRUTUS
