text: If you did, I care not.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: When Caesar lived he durst not thus have moved me.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Peace, peace! You durst not so have tempted him.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: I durst not?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: No.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: What? Durst not tempt him?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: For your life you durst not.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Do not presume too much upon my love. I may do that I shall be sorry for.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: You have done that you should be sorry for. There is no terror, Cassius, in your threats, For I am armed so strong in honesty That they pass by me as the idle wind,

speaker: CASSIUS
text: I denied you not.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: You did.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: I did not. He was but a fool that brought My answer back. Brutus hath rived my heart. A friend should bear his friend’s infirmities, But Brutus makes mine greater than they are.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: I do not, till you practice them on me.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: You love me not.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: I do not like your faults.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: A friendly eye could never see such faults.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: A flatterer’s would not, though they do appear As huge as high Olympus.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Come, Antony, and young Octavius, come! Revenge yourselves alone on Cassius, For Cassius is aweary of the world— Hated by one he loves, braved by his brother,

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Sheathe your dagger. Be angry when you will, it shall have scope. Do what you will, dishonor shall be humor. O Cassius, you are yokèd with a lamb That carries anger as the flint bears fire, Who, much enforcèd, shows a hasty spark And straight is cold again.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Hath Cassius lived To be but mirth and laughter to his Brutus When grief and blood ill-tempered vexeth him?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: When I spoke that, I was ill-tempered too.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Do you confess so much? Give me your hand.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: And my heart too. They clasp hands.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: O Brutus!

speaker: BRUTUS
text: What’s the matter?

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Have not you love enough to bear with me When that rash humor which my mother gave me Makes me forgetful?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Yes, Cassius, and from henceforth When you are over-earnest with your Brutus, He’ll think your mother chides, and leave you so. Enter a Poet followed by Lucilius, Titinius, and Lucius.

speaker: POET
text: Let me go in to see the Generals. There is some grudge between ’em; ’tis not meet They be alone.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text: You shall not come to them.

speaker: POET
text: Nothing but death shall stay me.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: How now, what’s the matter?

speaker: POET
text: For shame, you generals, what do you mean? Love and be friends as two such men should be, For I have seen more years, I’m sure, than ye.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Ha, ha, how vilely doth this cynic rhyme!

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Get you hence, sirrah! Saucy fellow, hence!

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Bear with him, Brutus. ’Tis his fashion.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: I’ll know his humor when he knows his time. What should the wars do with these jigging fools?— Companion, hence!

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Away, away, be gone! Poet exits.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Lucilius and Titinius, bid the commanders Prepare to lodge their companies tonight.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: And come yourselves, and bring Messala with you Immediately to us. Lucilius and Titinius exit.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Lucius, a bowl of wine. Lucius exits.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: I did not think you could have been so angry.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: O Cassius, I am sick of many griefs.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Of your philosophy you make no use If you give place to accidental evils.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: No man bears sorrow better. Portia is dead.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Ha? Portia?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: She is dead.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: How ’scaped I killing when I crossed you so? O insupportable and touching loss! Upon what sickness?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Impatient of my absence, And grief that young Octavius with Mark Antony Have made themselves so strong—for with her death That tidings came—with this she fell distract And, her attendants absent, swallowed fire.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: And died so?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Even so.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: O you immortal gods! Enter Lucius with wine and tapers.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Speak no more of her.—Give me a bowl of wine.— In this I bury all unkindness, Cassius. He drinks.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: My heart is thirsty for that noble pledge.— Fill, Lucius, till the wine o’erswell the cup; I cannot drink too much of Brutus’ love. He drinks. Lucius exits. Enter Titinius and Messala.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Come in, Titinius. Welcome, good Messala. Now sit we close about this taper here, And call in question our necessities. They sit.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Portia, art thou gone?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: No more, I pray you.— Messala, I have here receivèd letters That young Octavius and Mark Antony Come down upon us with a mighty power, Bending their expedition toward Philippi.

speaker: MESSALA
text: Myself have letters of the selfsame tenor.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: With what addition?

speaker: MESSALA
text: That by proscription and bills of outlawry, Octavius, Antony, and Lepidus Have put to death an hundred senators.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Therein our letters do not well agree. Mine speak of seventy senators that died By their proscriptions, Cicero being one.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Cicero one?

speaker: MESSALA
text: Cicero is dead, And by that order of proscription. Had you your letters from your wife, my lord?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: No, Messala.

speaker: MESSALA
text: Nor nothing in your letters writ of her?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Nothing, Messala.

speaker: MESSALA
text: That methinks is strange.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Why ask you? Hear you aught of her in yours?

speaker: MESSALA
text: No, my lord.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Now, as you are a Roman, tell me true.

speaker: MESSALA
text: Then like a Roman bear the truth I tell, For certain she is dead, and by strange manner.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Why, farewell, Portia. We must die, Messala. With meditating that she must die once, I have the patience to endure it now.

speaker: MESSALA
text: Even so great men great losses should endure.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: I have as much of this in art as you, But yet my nature could not bear it so.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Well, to our work alive. What do you think Of marching to Philippi presently?

speaker: CASSIUS
text: I do not think it good.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Your reason?

speaker: CASSIUS
text: This it is: ’Tis better that the enemy seek us; So shall he waste his means, weary his soldiers, Doing himself offense, whilst we, lying still, Are full of rest, defense, and nimbleness.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Good reasons must of force give place to better. The people ’twixt Philippi and this ground Do stand but in a forced affection, For they have grudged us contribution. The enemy, marching along by them, By them shall make a fuller number up, Come on refreshed, new-added, and encouraged, From which advantage shall we cut him off If at Philippi we do face him there, These people at our back.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Hear me, good brother—

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Under your pardon. You must note besides That we have tried the utmost of our friends, Our legions are brim full, our cause is ripe. The enemy increaseth every day; We, at the height, are ready to decline. There is a tide in the affairs of men Which, taken at the flood, leads on to fortune; Omitted, all the voyage of their life Is bound in shallows and in miseries. On such a full sea are we now afloat, And we must take the current when it serves Or lose our ventures.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Then, with your will, go on; We’ll along ourselves and meet them at Philippi.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: The deep of night is crept upon our talk, And nature must obey necessity, Which we will niggard with a little rest. There is no more to say.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: No more. Good night. They stand. Early tomorrow will we rise and hence.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Lucius. Enter Lucius. My gown. Lucius exits. Farewell, good Messala.— Good night, Titinius.—Noble, noble Cassius, Good night and good repose.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: O my dear brother, This was an ill beginning of the night. Never come such division ’tween our souls! Let it not, Brutus. Enter Lucius with the gown.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Everything is well.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Good night, my lord.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Good night, good brother. TITINIUS/MESSALA Good night, Lord Brutus.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Farewell, everyone. All but Brutus and Lucius exit. Give me the gown. Where is thy instrument?

speaker: LUCIUS
text: Here in the tent.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: What, thou speak’st drowsily? Poor knave, I blame thee not; thou art o’erwatched. Call Claudius and some other of my men; I’ll have them sleep on cushions in my tent.

speaker: LUCIUS
text: Varro and Claudius. Enter Varro and Claudius.

speaker: VARRO
text: Calls my lord?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: I pray you, sirs, lie in my tent and sleep. It may be I shall raise you by and by On business to my brother Cassius.

speaker: VARRO
text: So please you, we will stand and watch your pleasure.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: I will not have it so. Lie down, good sirs. It may be I shall otherwise bethink me. They lie down. Look, Lucius, here’s the book I sought for so. I put it in the pocket of my gown.

speaker: LUCIUS
text: I was sure your Lordship did not give it me.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Bear with me, good boy, I am much forgetful.

speaker: LUCIUS
text: Ay, my lord, an ’t please you.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: It does, my boy. I trouble thee too much, but thou art willing.

speaker: LUCIUS
text: It is my duty, sir.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: I should not urge thy duty past thy might. I know young bloods look for a time of rest.

speaker: LUCIUS
text: I have slept, my lord, already.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: It was well done, and thou shalt sleep again. I will not hold thee long. If I do live, I will be good to thee. Music and a song. Lucius then falls asleep. This is a sleepy tune. O murd’rous slumber, Layest thou thy leaden mace upon my boy, That plays thee music?—Gentle knave, good night. I will not do thee so much wrong to wake thee. If thou dost nod, thou break’st thy instrument. I’ll take it from thee and, good boy, good night. He moves the instrument. Let me see, let me see; is not the leaf turned down Where I left reading? Here it is, I think. How ill this taper burns. Enter the Ghost of Caesar. Ha, who comes here?— I think it is the weakness of mine eyes That shapes this monstrous apparition. It comes upon me.—Art thou any thing? Art thou some god, some angel, or some devil, That mak’st my blood cold and my hair to stare? Speak to me what thou art.

speaker: GHOST
text: Thy evil spirit, Brutus.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Why com’st thou?

speaker: GHOST
text: To tell thee thou shalt see me at Philippi.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Well, then I shall see thee again?

speaker: GHOST
text: Ay, at Philippi.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Why, I will see thee at Philippi, then. Ghost exits. Now I have taken heart, thou vanishest. Ill spirit, I would hold more talk with thee.— Boy, Lucius!—Varro, Claudius, sirs, awake! Claudius!

speaker: LUCIUS
text: The strings, my lord, are false.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: He thinks he still is at his instrument. Lucius, awake!

speaker: LUCIUS
text: My lord?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Didst thou dream, Lucius, that thou so criedst out?

speaker: LUCIUS
text: My lord, I do not know that I did cry.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Yes, that thou didst. Didst thou see anything?

speaker: LUCIUS
text: Nothing, my lord.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Sleep again, Lucius.—Sirrah Claudius! To Varro. Fellow thou, awake! They rise up.

speaker: VARRO
text: My lord?

speaker: CLAUDIUS
text: My lord?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Why did you so cry out, sirs, in your sleep?

speaker: BOTH
text: Did we, my lord?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Ay. Saw you anything?

speaker: VARRO
text: No, my lord, I saw nothing.

speaker: CLAUDIUS
text: Nor I, my lord.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Go and commend me to my brother Cassius. Bid him set on his powers betimes before, And we will follow.

speaker: BOTH
text: It shall be done, my lord. They exit.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text: Now, Antony, our hopes are answerèd. You said the enemy would not come down But keep the hills and upper regions. It proves not so; their battles are at hand. They mean to warn us at Philippi here, Answering before we do demand of them.

speaker: ANTONY
text: Tut, I am in their bosoms, and I know Wherefore they do it. They could be content To visit other places, and come down With fearful bravery, thinking by this face To fasten in our thoughts that they have courage. But ’tis not so. Enter a Messenger.

speaker: MESSENGER
text: Prepare you, generals. The enemy comes on in gallant show. Their bloody sign of battle is hung out, And something to be done immediately.

speaker: ANTONY
text: Octavius, lead your battle softly on Upon the left hand of the even field.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text: Upon the right hand, I; keep thou the left.

speaker: ANTONY
text: Why do you cross me in this exigent?

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text: I do not cross you, but I will do so. March. Drum. Enter Brutus, Cassius, and their army including Lucilius, Titinius, and Messala.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: They stand and would have parley.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Stand fast, Titinius. We must out and talk.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text: Mark Antony, shall we give sign of battle?

speaker: ANTONY
text: No, Caesar, we will answer on their charge. Make forth. The Generals would have some words. OCTAVIUS, to his Officers Stir not until the signal. The Generals step forward.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Words before blows; is it so, countrymen?

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text: Not that we love words better, as you do.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Good words are better than bad strokes, Octavius.

speaker: ANTONY
text: In your bad strokes, Brutus, you give good words. Witness the hole you made in Caesar’s heart, Crying “Long live, hail, Caesar!”

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Antony, The posture of your blows are yet unknown, But, for your words, they rob the Hybla bees And leave them honeyless.

speaker: ANTONY
text: Not stingless too.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: O yes, and soundless too,

speaker: ANTONY
text: Villains, you did not so when your vile daggers Hacked one another in the sides of Caesar. You showed your teeth like apes and fawned like hounds And bowed like bondmen, kissing Caesar’s feet, Whilst damnèd Casca, like a cur, behind Struck Caesar on the neck. O you flatterers!

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Flatterers?—Now, Brutus, thank yourself! This tongue had not offended so today If Cassius might have ruled.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text: Come, come, the cause. If arguing make us sweat, The proof of it will turn to redder drops. Look, I draw a sword against conspirators; He draws. When think you that the sword goes up again? Never, till Caesar’s three and thirty wounds Be well avenged, or till another Caesar Have added slaughter to the sword of traitors.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Caesar, thou canst not die by traitors’ hands Unless thou bring’st them with thee.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text: So I hope. I was not born to die on Brutus’ sword.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: O, if thou wert the noblest of thy strain, Young man, thou couldst not die more honorable.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: A peevish schoolboy, worthless of such honor, Joined with a masker and a reveler!

speaker: ANTONY
text: Old Cassius still.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text: Come, Antony, away!—

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Why now, blow wind, swell billow, and swim bark! The storm is up, and all is on the hazard.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Ho, Lucilius, hark, a word with you. Lucilius and Messala stand forth.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text: My lord? Brutus and Lucilius step aside together.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Messala.

speaker: MESSALA
text: What says my general?

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Messala, This is my birthday, as this very day Was Cassius born. Give me thy hand, Messala. Be thou my witness that against my will (As Pompey was) am I compelled to set Upon one battle all our liberties. You know that I held Epicurus strong And his opinion. Now I change my mind And partly credit things that do presage. Coming from Sardis, on our former ensign Two mighty eagles fell, and there they perched, Gorging and feeding from our soldiers’ hands, Who to Philippi here consorted us. This morning are they fled away and gone, And in their steads do ravens, crows, and kites Fly o’er our heads and downward look on us As we were sickly prey. Their shadows seem A canopy most fatal, under which Our army lies, ready to give up the ghost.

speaker: MESSALA
text: Believe not so.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: I but believe it partly, For I am fresh of spirit and resolved To meet all perils very constantly.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Even so, Lucilius. Brutus returns to Cassius.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Now, most noble Brutus, The gods today stand friendly that we may, Lovers in peace, lead on our days to age. But since the affairs of men rests still incertain, Let’s reason with the worst that may befall. If we do lose this battle, then is this The very last time we shall speak together. What are you then determinèd to do?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Even by the rule of that philosophy By which I did blame Cato for the death Which he did give himself (I know not how, But I do find it cowardly and vile, For fear of what might fall, so to prevent The time of life), arming myself with patience To stay the providence of some high powers That govern us below.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Then, if we lose this battle, You are contented to be led in triumph Thorough the streets of Rome?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: No, Cassius, no. Think not, thou noble Roman, That ever Brutus will go bound to Rome. He bears too great a mind. But this same day Must end that work the ides of March begun. And whether we shall meet again, I know not. Therefore our everlasting farewell take. Forever and forever farewell, Cassius. If we do meet again, why we shall smile; If not, why then this parting was well made.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Forever and forever farewell, Brutus. If we do meet again, we’ll smile indeed; If not, ’tis true this parting was well made.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Why then, lead on.—O, that a man might know The end of this day’s business ere it come! But it sufficeth that the day will end, And then the end is known.—Come ho, away! They exit.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Ride, ride, Messala, ride, and give these bills Unto the legions on the other side! He hands Messala papers. Loud alarum. Let them set on at once, for I perceive But cold demeanor in Octavius’ wing, And sudden push gives them the overthrow. Ride, ride, Messala! Let them all come down. They exit.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: O, look, Titinius, look, the villains fly! Myself have to mine own turned enemy. This ensign here of mine was turning back; I slew the coward and did take it from him.

speaker: TITINIUS
text: O Cassius, Brutus gave the word too early, Who, having some advantage on Octavius, Took it too eagerly. His soldiers fell to spoil, Whilst we by Antony are all enclosed. Enter Pindarus.

speaker: PINDARUS
text: Fly further off, my lord, fly further off! Mark Antony is in your tents, my lord. Fly therefore, noble Cassius, fly far off.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: This hill is far enough.—Look, look, Titinius, Are those my tents where I perceive the fire?

speaker: TITINIUS
text: They are, my lord.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Titinius, if thou lovest me, Mount thou my horse and hide thy spurs in him Till he have brought thee up to yonder troops And here again, that I may rest assured Whether yond troops are friend or enemy.

speaker: TITINIUS
text: I will be here again even with a thought. He exits.

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Go, Pindarus, get higher on that hill. My sight was ever thick. Regard Titinius And tell me what thou not’st about the field. Pindarus goes up. This day I breathèd first. Time is come round, And where I did begin, there shall I end; My life is run his compass.—Sirrah, what news? PINDARUS, above. O my lord!

speaker: CASSIUS
text: What news?

speaker: PINDARUS
text: Titinius is enclosèd round about

speaker: CASSIUS
text: Come down, behold no more.— O, coward that I am to live so long To see my best friend ta’en before my face! Pindarus comes down. Come hither, sirrah. In Parthia did I take thee prisoner, And then I swore thee, saving of thy life, That whatsoever I did bid thee do Thou shouldst attempt it. Come now, keep thine oath. Now be a freeman, and with this good sword, That ran through Caesar’s bowels, search this bosom. Stand not to answer. Here, take thou the hilts, And, when my face is covered, as ’tis now, Guide thou the sword. Pindarus stabs him. Caesar, thou art revenged Even with the sword that killed thee. He dies.

speaker: PINDARUS
text: So I am free, yet would not so have been, Durst I have done my will.—O Cassius!— Far from this country Pindarus shall run, Where never Roman shall take note of him. He exits. Enter Titinius and Messala.

speaker: MESSALA
text: It is but change, Titinius, for Octavius Is overthrown by noble Brutus’ power, As Cassius’ legions are by Antony.

speaker: TITINIUS
text: These tidings will well comfort Cassius.

speaker: MESSALA
text: Where did you leave him?

speaker: TITINIUS
text: All disconsolate, With Pindarus his bondman, on this hill.

speaker: MESSALA
text: Is not that he that lies upon the ground?

speaker: TITINIUS
text: He lies not like the living. O my heart!

speaker: MESSALA
text: Is not that he?

speaker: TITINIUS
text: No, this was he, Messala, But Cassius is no more. O setting sun, As in thy red rays thou dost sink to night, So in his red blood Cassius’ day is set. The sun of Rome is set. Our day is gone; Clouds, dews, and dangers come. Our deeds are done. Mistrust of my success hath done this deed.

speaker: MESSALA
text: Mistrust of good success hath done this deed. O hateful error, melancholy’s child, Why dost thou show to the apt thoughts of men The things that are not? O error, soon conceived, Thou never com’st unto a happy birth But kill’st the mother that engendered thee!

speaker: TITINIUS
text: What, Pindarus! Where art thou, Pindarus?

speaker: MESSALA
text: Seek him, Titinius, whilst I go to meet The noble Brutus, thrusting this report Into his ears. I may say “thrusting it,” For piercing steel and darts envenomèd Shall be as welcome to the ears of Brutus As tidings of this sight.

speaker: TITINIUS
text: Hie you, Messala, And I will seek for Pindarus the while. Messala exits. Why didst thou send me forth, brave Cassius? Did I not meet thy friends, and did not they Put on my brows this wreath of victory And bid me give it thee? Didst thou not hear their shouts? Alas, thou hast misconstrued everything. But hold thee, take this garland on thy brow. Laying the garland on Cassius’ brow. Thy Brutus bid me give it thee, and I Will do his bidding.—Brutus, come apace, And see how I regarded Caius Cassius.— By your leave, gods, this is a Roman’s part. Come, Cassius’ sword, and find Titinius’ heart! He dies on Cassius’ sword. Alarum. Enter Brutus, Messala, young Cato, Strato, Volumnius, and Lucilius, Labeo, and Flavius.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Where, where, Messala, doth his body lie?

speaker: MESSALA
text: Lo, yonder, and Titinius mourning it.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Titinius’ face is upward.

speaker: CATO
text: He is slain.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: O Julius Caesar, thou art mighty yet; Thy spirit walks abroad and turns our swords In our own proper entrails. Low alarums.

speaker: CATO
text: Brave Titinius!— Look whe’er he have not crowned dead Cassius.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Are yet two Romans living such as these?— The last of all the Romans, fare thee well.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Yet, countrymen, O, yet hold up your heads! Brutus, Messala, and Flavius exit.

speaker: CATO
text: What bastard doth not? Who will go with me? I will proclaim my name about the field. I am the son of Marcus Cato, ho! A foe to tyrants and my country’s friend. I am the son of Marcus Cato, ho! Enter Soldiers and fight.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text: And I am Brutus, Marcus Brutus, I! Brutus, my country’s friend! Know me for Brutus. Cato is killed. O young and noble Cato, art thou down?

speaker: FIRST
text: SOLDIER, seizing Lucilius Yield, or thou diest.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text: Only I yield to die. There is so much that thou wilt kill me straight. Offering money. Kill Brutus and be honored in his death.

speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
text: We must not. A noble prisoner! Enter Antony.

speaker: SECOND SOLDIER
text: Room, ho! Tell Antony Brutus is ta’en.

speaker: FIRST SOLDIER
text: I’ll tell the news. Here comes the General.— Brutus is ta’en, Brutus is ta’en, my lord.

speaker: ANTONY
text: Where is he?

speaker: LUCILIUS
text: Safe, Antony, Brutus is safe enough. I dare assure thee that no enemy Shall ever take alive the noble Brutus. The gods defend him from so great a shame! When you do find him, or alive or dead, He will be found like Brutus, like himself.

speaker: ANTONY
text: This is not Brutus, friend, but I assure you, A prize no less in worth. Keep this man safe. Give him all kindness. I had rather have Such men my friends than enemies. Go on, And see whe’er Brutus be alive or dead, And bring us word unto Octavius’ tent How everything is chanced. They exit in different directions.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Come, poor remains of friends, rest on this rock. He sits down.

speaker: CLITUS
text: Statilius showed the torchlight, but, my lord, He came not back. He is or ta’en or slain.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Sit thee down, Clitus. Slaying is the word; It is a deed in fashion. Hark thee, Clitus. He whispers to Clitus.

speaker: CLITUS
text: What, I, my lord? No, not for all the world.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Peace, then, no words.

speaker: CLITUS
text: I’ll rather kill myself.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Hark thee, Dardanus. He whispers to Dardanus.

speaker: DARDANUS
text: Shall I do such a deed?

speaker: CLITUS
text: O Dardanus!

speaker: DARDANUS
text: O Clitus! Dardanus and Clitus step aside.

speaker: CLITUS
text: What ill request did Brutus make to thee?

speaker: DARDANUS
text: To kill him, Clitus. Look, he meditates.

speaker: CLITUS
text: Now is that noble vessel full of grief, That it runs over even at his eyes.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Come hither, good Volumnius. List a word.

speaker: VOLUMNIUS
text: What says my lord?

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Why this, Volumnius:

speaker: VOLUMNIUS
text: Not so, my lord.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Nay, I am sure it is, Volumnius. Thou seest the world, Volumnius, how it goes. Our enemies have beat us to the pit. Low alarums. It is more worthy to leap in ourselves Than tarry till they push us. Good Volumnius, Thou know’st that we two went to school together; Even for that our love of old, I prithee, Hold thou my sword hilts whilst I run on it.

speaker: VOLUMNIUS
text: That’s not an office for a friend, my lord. Alarum continues.

speaker: CLITUS
text: Fly, fly, my lord! There is no tarrying here.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Farewell to you—and you—and you, Volumnius.— Strato, thou hast been all this while asleep. Farewell to thee, too, Strato.—Countrymen, My heart doth joy that yet in all my life I found no man but he was true to me. I shall have glory by this losing day More than Octavius and Mark Antony By this vile conquest shall attain unto. So fare you well at once, for Brutus’ tongue Hath almost ended his life’s history. Night hangs upon mine eyes; my bones would rest, That have but labored to attain this hour. Alarum. Cry within “Fly, fly, fly!”

speaker: CLITUS
text: Fly, my lord, fly!

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Hence. I will follow. All exit but Brutus and Strato.

speaker: STRATO
text: Give me your hand first. Fare you well, my lord.

speaker: BRUTUS
text: Farewell, good Strato. Brutus runs on his sword. Caesar, now be still. I killed not thee with half so good a will. He dies. Alarum. Retreat. Enter Antony, Octavius, Messala, Lucilius, and the army.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text: What man is that?

speaker: MESSALA
text: My master’s man.—Strato, where is thy master?

speaker: STRATO
text: Free from the bondage you are in, Messala. The conquerors can but make a fire of him, For Brutus only overcame himself, And no man else hath honor by his death.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text: So Brutus should be found.—I thank thee, Brutus, That thou hast proved Lucilius’ saying true.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text: All that served Brutus, I will entertain them.— Fellow, wilt thou bestow thy time with me?

speaker: STRATO
text: Ay, if Messala will prefer me to you.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text: Do so, good Messala.

speaker: MESSALA
text: How died my master, Strato?

speaker: STRATO
text: I held the sword, and he did run on it.

speaker: MESSALA
text: Octavius, then take him to follow thee, That did the latest service to my master.

speaker: ANTONY
text: This was the noblest Roman of them all. All the conspirators save only he Did that they did in envy of great Caesar. He only in a general honest thought And common good to all made one of them. His life was gentle and the elements So mixed in him that nature might stand up And say to all the world “This was a man.”

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text: According to his virtue, let us use him With all respect and rites of burial. Within my tent his bones tonight shall lie, Most like a soldier, ordered honorably. So call the field to rest, and let’s away To part the glories of this happy day. They all exit.
